Message.Title: Tumblr & Summly Integration
Message.Msg: From an article I just found. What most people misunderstand about Tumblr, and what Yahoo may feel is worth paying for, is that Tumblr is NOT best described as a "blogging platform." Sure, users have blogs on which they post things. But once you're a Tumblr user, you find that the real fun of Tumblr is building a news feed that only you can see from other users you like. Want an all-skateboarding-all-the-time news feed? Tumblr. As members begin to follow each other, they start messaging each other. The real party on Tumblr is going on behind the dashboard, not on the blogs' outer faces. That party is why Tumblr has become so big among young people — it's basically a cool social hangout that their parents haven't figured out yet. Tumblr's dashboard feeds are obviously easy to monetize in the future, just as Facebook and Instagram's friend feeds are and will be. Which is why $1 billion suddenly doesn't seem completely crazy for a $13 million startup. Read more: http://www.businessinsider.com/why-yahoo-might-pay-1-billion-for-tumblr-2013-5#ixzz2Tdzay0ay

Message.Title: Tumblr + Yahoo! a Facebook killer?

Young people do not want to hang out where their parent hangout. 2.Blogers are exiting because they lose control of their creation on FB. MM has said that the future of content creation is data ownership where, if the creator leaves, they can take their data with them. If she can apply this in their venture it will distroy FB preference from famous bloggers.
We'll know in 2-3 years time.

At the World Economic Forum in late January in Davos, Switzerland, Yahoo! CEO Marissa Mayer talked about many things, including the benefits of data portability. In Mayer’s view, users should “own” their data and be able to easily export/remove it from one application or service and import it into another. This is the promise to Tumbler that will get the deal, and will surprise all the tec world. If both announcements are forthcomming this is a $35+ by summer.

Message.Title: 1.1 B Too Low?!?
Message.Msg: Tumblr May Reject Yahoo's $1.1B Acquisition Offer For Being “Too Low” 88 1010 by JOSH CONSTINE posted 13 Hours Ago Tumblr feels that Yahoo’s $1.1 billion offer is “too low” and views it as “only a first offer,” according to sources close to acquisition talks. Yahoo may have to significantly increase the offer to close the deal. An acquisition by some tech giant is likely in the cards for Tumblr, though, as sources say the company only has a few months of cash runway left. The news comes after AllThingsD reported Yahoo was in advanced talks to buy Tumblr for $1.1 billion cash, and the portal’s board of directors are set to meet on Sunday night to discuss the potential deal. Forbes reports that Facebook and Microsoft have also expressed interest in acquiring Tumblr. However, Forbes says that Yahoo has lock-up agreement arranged with Tumblr that prevents the blogging platform from holding a “bake-off” or bidding war for the right to buy it. If Yahoo comes to the table with an insufficient offer, which our sources say $1.1 billion qualifies as, Tumblr may be able to reject it and shop itself around some more. A few months ago Tumblr let several companies know it was interested in possibly being acquired. Yahoo was the first to come to the table with a firm number, says one of our sources. They say Tumblr is apprehensive about accepting the $1.1 billion cash offer, though. Considering the much smaller, younger Instagram’s acquisition price was supposed to be $1 billion (in cash and stock, though, which would eventually make it worth less), it seems reasonable that Tumblr would view $1.1 billion cash as a lowball. Tumblr employees have been told that the company only has enough funds to operate for a few more months, as its costs far exceed the limited revenue it earns. Tumblr pulled in $13 million in 2012, but has accelerated its advertising offering in hopes of hitting $100 million in revenue this year. The money’s not coming in fast enough to support its expenses though. Employees were recently told not to be concerned, though, because the company is expecting to be bought. Of course, Yahoo might be able to push the deal through for $1.1 billion or just a little more depending on how the acquisition is structured. If it promises Tumblr’s CEO David Karp he can retain control of the company, provides the right retention bonuses, or won’t force Tumblr to shoehorn in integrations with Yahoo’s other properties, Tumblr may be more receptive. If Yahoo successfully buys the startup, it could inject some much-needed “cool,” youthful energy, and design sense into the aging tech giant. The acquisition might not be so popular with Tumblr’s users, though, who range from young hipsters to diehard Internet aficionados. Many thought Instagram’s user base would balk at its acquisition by Facebook, but the photo sharing service has continued to grow, offering some hope to Yahoo and Tumblr if their deal closes.

Topic.Title: What Do Disheartened FaceBook Investors Do Knowing Yahoo Snags Tumblr?

Message.Msg: From Forbes article this afternoon. Tumblr And Yahoo: Latest Details On The Imminent Deal SHARE: Soon-to-be quarter-billionaire David Karp. (Image credit: Getty Images via @daylife) By the end of this weekend, Tumblr founder David Karp will most likely be $250 million richer and Yahoo founder Marissa Mayer will be able to say she outmaneuvered her old friends at Google, not to mention Facebook, Twitter and Microsoft. Yahoo’s board will meet Sunday to vote on a $1.1 billion offer the company has put forth for Tumblr, the six-year-old social blogging platform. Details of the offer were first reported by All Things D; I’ve independently confirmed them with sources close to the proceedings and learned a few additional facts. The meeting had to happen fast because an agreement that gives Yahoo the exclusive right to negotiate one-on-one with Tumblr is set to expire in just a few days. Were that window to close without a deal, the Tumblr derby could turn into a real free-for all. In addition to Facebook and Microsoft, two companies that I reported earlier have held talks with Tumblr, I’ve also learned that Google and Twitter have made approaches in recent weeks. In fact, it was an expression of interest from Google, which was looking to possibly make an investment in or acquire the company, that set off the furious round of tire-kicking that culminated in Yahoo’s bid. While there’s been some speculation that another party could still emerge with a better offer, it’s pretty unlikely at this point. Tumblr’s board, which includes representatives from Union Square Ventures, Spark Capital and Sequoia Capital, has already voted to approve Yahoo’s offer. Given Yahoo’s large war chest from the sale of its Alibaba stake and the relatively free hand Mayer enjoys as a new CEO, it’s expected that her board will go along willingly as well. For a third party to derail the deal, then, would require an extraordinarily aggressive gesture, on the order of Mark Zuckerberg calling up Karp and promising him hundreds of millions more. No one’s expecting that. Inside Tumblr, the thinking is that Yahoo’s offer is likely to be as good as it gets because none of other big players need what Tumblr offers — its youth, its growth, its high levels of mobile engagement — quite so badly. On Friday afternoon, Tumblr had its regular weekly all-hands meeting at its Manhattan headquarters. Naturally, someone asked Karp about the sale reports. Karp — who is believed to own more than 20% of Tumblr’s equity — downplayed them, promising employees that they would be the first to know any big news.

I just hope next week enough suckers come along so I can reduce my position significantly(50-75%).

LMAO so you have NOTHING civil you resort to non-sense huh? Always the sign of low intelligence and to think you were the one calling me not smart. Topic.Title: What Do Disheartened FaceBook Investors Do Knowing Yahoo Snags Tumblr?

Message.Msg: Worse for FB shareholders already have butterflies in their bellies. There will be a lot of shorting on FB. I feel for the shareholders. Maybe Zuckenberg can work some magic, but I wouldn't want to be holding FB next week.

I can of agree with hotmodel about the price, it's too steep. But then the alternatives are even worst. 1. Yahoo let this stream option die away... 2.Somebody else buys them and make Yahoo smaller in proportion to the market (market share killer). I think the move is timely and from what we have learn on MM, she is a shrewd negotiator (all adquihires with $10M!), I think the media "rumors" come from Tumblr to force the close out, its being reported that their boar already approved the deal. We will later learn that if it comes to the $1.1B (I doubt it) it will have a lot of conditions, that will make it much less than that (but they will not loose face publicly). PS: Hotmodel keep posting I like your no-nonse reality check, it keeps me honest.

Message.Title: YHOO going higher not just one way but in two fronts
Message.Msg: This is unique. Two powerful forces (Asian assets and YHOO core) pushing or uplifting YHOO in the $30 to $35 per YHOO share this year. That's how powerful YHOO uptrend movements. This is unbelievable but YHOO is finally getting her fortune and it is unstoppable. Enjoy this goldmine ride folks.

Topic.Title: What is the symple for tumblr

Message.Msg: Oh I get 'IT", but please elaborate on your thoughts, which judging by your statement, you feel this acquisition will be beneficial. But before you do, I just want to disclose that I am a tumblr user and have been a yahoo investor both long and short over the past few years. From my tumblr perspective, I am not excited about this deal. In fact, if they make a single change to the platform I will completely drop it, like I did FB a few years back. From an investors perspective, I don't like companies that overpay for a company whose real revenue is really jsut plain silly and even questionable. If social media investments were soooo good, then facebook would not be trading below its IPO price, it would be at all time highs. Tumblr will never be Facebook, so that begs the question of how much value added tumblr can add to yahoo, if Facebook has weak value.

Message.Title: Horrible decision
Message.Msg: I'm #$%$ off. MM needs to buy established businesses. She is about my age. She should be aware of the internet bubble back in 2000. She sure looks stupid buying a business for 1 billion that has revenue of 100 million but no net income. With this transaction, she really shows she's out of her league as a ceo. Once Alibaba goes public I am out.
Well they don't actually have revenue of 100 million - they are projected to have 100 million this year. Last year they had 13 million.

Message.Title: lol, tumblr? Nobody uses that piece of garbage anymore
Message.Msg: pure comedy

And that's not profits......that's revenue. So why spend 1 billion on a company that may or may not be successful. What makes warren buffet great is that he is not worried about being cool. He wants growing business that are predictable and profitable. Tumblr is none of the above. We can only hope microsoft swoops in with a higher bid.

What is the world coming to when we agree on something?!?!?! This is literally a dollar out of your pocket for every share you own and in return you get 1/10 of a PENNY in return and that is just revenue as profit is nil. The difference between FAIR PRICE and this ASTRONOMICAL price is hope/hype/synergy/value creation that I have doubts can be made from Tumblr. Why exactly can't Yahoo create Yahumblr Pie, as sweet as mama's apple pie? Throw in recipe pinning like Pinterest, blogging like Tumblr and 200 characters like Tweetjeesus with some commercial free Yahoo TV shows. Oh and we'll tie it to EVERY email account so instantly 700M users or whatever. 7X bigger than Tumblr which makes my idea worth $7.7B! Why win the Powerball when I just created something over 10X bigger?hahahahahahahaha If they're that close to BK why not call their bluff and buy them later for dirt cheap? Their burn rate was TWICE revenue($25M vs. $13M) If a bigger fool comes along...fine its better to make no deal than a bad deal. Makes me wonder what Reddit is truly worth as I've been to that site more than Tumblr.
Warren Buffett famously stays away from tech. Have to say I don't find it very interesting & I don't yet see where the social aspect comes in. But, I guess it's all about the eyeballs for Yahoo!.

Geocities Good one. Nice 1999 reference that you read in an article today that is completely irrelevant to the tumblr purchase. Go grab another sixer of Schlitz and stop thinking you are smarter than MM because I can assure you that you aren't.
You are a sexist clout, Fool!

Jojo, I think you should give her the benefit of doubt here. She is trying. You can't say that of the last five CEOs. $1bil is not the issue. It remains to be seen what come of this purchase. If successful, she will look like a genius and $1bil was dirt cheap. If it fails, then of course the money was a wasted and paid way too much. One thing is for sure...I like her chances. She is really sharp executive and I would assume she already has plans for them before the buyout was even done. Just look at the summly buy... They bought and integrated the summly technology all within a month. Have you ever seen that kind of execution? Ever? That blew my mind how quickly it was done and we just may see history repeat itself here.

Message.Title: I never heard of Tumblr until this buyout rumor started...
Message.Msg: Now I can't wait to set up my own Tumblr blog. From what I'm reading, there's a lot of trashy punks on there, porn and useless information. But once they're brought into the Yahoo! fold it will be a pretty cool site. Those Tumblr's who are protesting don't make the site any money anyway, but people like me who actually have money, will buy from the advertisers we see. I like it, and I'm a shareholder.
Holding both YHOO and BRKB long and strong. I think there is merit to both kinds of investors. Still, a Billion dollars? Hmmmmm....
What do you think?
Right again.

Message.Title: why would yahoo get into the laundromat business??
Message.Msg: i can understand them setting up wi-fi at laundromats across the country but to buy the biggest manufacturer of tumble dryers just doesnt make sense to me???

Agreed. What I find interesting is that in Sept/11, they received 85million in a round that included Richard Branson, Greylock etc.. It brought them a lot of attention & they were valued at that time around 800 million. I see in Nov/12 there was talk about Tumblr about to get another round of funding - which would value them at 1 Billion, but I don't see that they actually ever received that round of funding. So a year and half ago they were already valued at 800 million & they had negligible revenue. I guess you're worth what someone is willing to pay you (~~,

Message.Msg: There are a lot of dirty clothes out there Jimmy a lot. (~~,

You said: "I guess you're worth what someone is willing to pay you." I say: "Exactly. For better or for worse. Fingers crossed. " Bless us one and all.....
